report_title: Commercial Service Machinery Manufacturing Industry Report
executive_summary: Manufacturers in this industry produce a broad range of products, including copiers and office machinery, commercial cooking equipment, vacuum cleaners and vending machines. Volatile macroeconomic conditions during the COVID-19 pandemic suppressed commercial demand, depressing the need for both office machinery and commercial food preparation equipment from the industry's largest markets. Overall, revenue is expected to have increased at a CAGR of 0.2% through the end of 2024 to reach $30.8 billion, including an expected 1.1% depression in 2024 alone. Profit is expected to have grown marginally to 8.3% of revenue in 2024, up from 8.2% in 2019.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Overall revenue expected to expand at 2.0% CAGR through 2029
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: Overall, revenue is expected to expand at a CAGR of 2.0% through the end of 2029 to reach $34.0 billion. Also, profit is expected to rise to 8.8% of revenue.

Copier and optical products like photographic and photocopying equipment have suffered from import penetration and a rising trend toward digital cameras and video recorders, which now come standard on mobile phones. Trade plays a critical role in the industry. The pandemic in 2020 significantly impaired international trade, depressing imports and exports. Manufacturers seized this opportunity to fill a greater portion of domestic demand, forming closer bonds with downstream consumers.

Demand from downstream wholesale and retail customers is driven by corporate profit and aggregate private investment. When corporate profit is high, businesses make industry-relevant equipment upgrades and acquisitions. Office rental vacancies soared in 2020 because most office-bound jobs moved to remote working environments to curb the spread of the virus. Vacancies have shrunk as employers returned to the office, though remain high compared with pre-pandemic levels.
Increased input prices and weaker downstream demand have caused industry consolidation. Despite this, no manufacturer holds more than 5% market share.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Demand for products will pick up
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Catalysts for industry demand will include corporate profit and aggregate private investment. An anticipated jump in corporate profit will spur investments in new machinery and equipment. Also, projected growth in aggregate private investment will likely coincide with increased machinery and equipment purchases by businesses. Consumer spending is expected to swell as the economy grows. This boost in spending will likely result in heightened need for the industry's various products, especially from downstream commercial retailers and restaurants.

- Increased demand for products from the food service industry will lead to higher demand for commercial ovens, ranges and cooking equipment through the end of 2028. - Commercial construction projects are expected to encounter minimal to no delays as the general health of the overall economy is projected to remain stable through the end of 2028. - The need for commercial washers, dryers and dry-cleaning equipment is expected to grow, driven by increasing utility costs which incentivize more significant investment in energy-efficient washers and dryers.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Exports will grow and the industry will consolidate
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: The industry is expected to benefit from the easing trade gap. The value of the US dollar is expected to wane in the coming years, opening the industry up to increasing export activity to expanding economies. Exports are expected to expand while imports fall, indicating stronger relationships between domestic manufacturers and downstream markets. This will allow prominent manufacturers specializing in a specific product line to solidify their positions, increasing their market share and raising the barrier to entry.

industry_definition: This industry mainly manufactures commercial cooking equipment, floor-cleaning machines (excluding residential vacuums), electronic teaching machines and automotive maintenance equipment (excluding hand tools). Operators also manufacture parts for service-industry equipment; optical instruments and lenses; copiers and office machinery (excluding printers); photographic equipment (excluding digital); automatic vending machines; and commercial laundry and dry-cleaning equipment.
key_trends: Import penetration is the main source of external competition for the industry. Imports satisfy nearly half of all domestic demand.

Some manufacturers manage to dominate their respective product segments to the point of obtaining a significant market share. For instance, Xerox holds much of the total photographic and photocopying equipment product segment.
Trade plays a critical role in the industry. The pandemic in 2020 significantly impaired international trade, both at the export and import levels.

Wage and purchase costs have increased and have slowed revenue growth. Rising merger and acquisition activity has increased consolidation within the industry, contributing to the declining number of enterprises.

Welbilt, a manufacturer of commercial cooking equipment, dominates this category for miscellaneous commercial and service machinery. Xerox holds a large proportional share of the total photographic and photocopying equipment product segment as a result of the company's copier machine sales.

Rinnai, a Japanese company with overseas holdings in the United States and Korea, holds the greatest market share in the industry. Rinnai manufactures a broad range of products but specializes in commercial-use food preparation equipment.

market_segmentation.segment_description: Because of the diverse nature of the industry, manufacturers specializing in each product segment conduct significant business with their respective downstream wholesaling industries. Likewise, the Camera and Film Wholesalers industry requires camera equipment manufactured by optical machinery manufacturers, while the Copier and Office Equipment Wholesaling industry demands photocopiers and office equipment. Demand from camera-related markets has suffered at the hands of increasing digital substitution and the inclusion of cameras on many phone models. Meanwhile, demand from the office-related markets has grown as an overall increase in corporate profit levels encouraged businesses to purchase copiers and optical products.

In addition to relevant wholesale markets, each product segment also caters to its relevant downstream industry of the retail market. Manufacturers provide full-service restaurants, food service contractors, bakeries and other dining establishments with commercial-type ranges, dishwashers and more. Declining demand form direct sales was driven by COVID-19-related establishment closures in 2020. As the economy recovered in 2021 and 2022, demand from this market segment rose. Demand from public and private schools, universities, hospitals and other healthcare facilities is a major driver of industry performance.

products_and_services.product_description: More than half of segment revenue is generated from the sale of miscellaneous optical instruments, including binoculars and telescopes. The remaining revenue is from selling optical-type sighting, tracking and fire-control equipment.

This segment includes hand-type still and other cameras for photolithography and photoengraving; projectors; commercial-type processing equipment; motion picture equipment and related processors; projection screens for movies or stills and photocopying equipment.

products_and_services.product_or_service: Commercial and Industrial Vacuum Cleaners and Automotive Equipment

products_and_services.product_description: Industry products are diverse, including electronic teaching machines, aids and kits; commercial and industrial floor-cleaning machines; automotive maintenance equipment and other service-industry equipment ranging from carnival and amusement park rides to mop wringers. The work-from-home model has boosted the need for electronic teaching machines. Manufacturers have integrated evolving technologies into electronic teaching products, increasing demand from downstream markets.

products_and_services.product_or_service: Service Industry, Commercial Cookware and Food Warming Equipment
products_and_services.product_description: Demand for commercial cooking and food-warming equipment wavered during the COVID-19 pandemic because restaurants were forced to close due to social distancing requirements. As restrictions eased, the need for commercial cooking equipment spiked.

tier_1_suppliers: Copier & Optical Machinery Manufacturing in the US
tier_2_suppliers: Electrical Equipment Manufacturing in the US
Industrial Machinery & Equipment Wholesaling in the US
Molybdenum & Metal Ore Mining in the US
tier_1_buyers: Accommodation and Food Services in the US
Finance and Insurance in the US
Professional, Scientific and Technical Services in the US
Vending Machine Operators in the US

demand_determinants.determinant_title: A shift toward digital photography has reduced the need for analog photo-processing equipment.
demand_determinants.determinant_description: Also, digital phone cameras have emerged as competitors for traditional camera sales.

international_trade_points.trade_description: Optical instruments also account for the majority of import demand, with one-half of all domestic demand for the industry's products attributable to these products. Imported office machinery comes in a distant third, with an estimated one-quarter of all import sales.

China and Japan dominate US imports of photo and office equipment. China caters to bulk, cost-effective demand, while Japan targets the high-quality, limited-quantity segment, serving both extremes of downstream demand.

international_trade_points.trade_title: Exports are expected to rise after subdued performance
international_trade_points.trade_description: Exports have shrunk slightly largely because of lingering supply chain issues caused by the COVID-19 pandemic. Also, the proliferation of smartphones has depressed global demand for copiers and optical machinery, the industry's primary products.

international_trade_points.trade_title: Rising economies in the top import destinations
international_trade_points.trade_description: Optical instruments consistently account for more than one-half of sales to foreign markets. China, South Korea and Canada are among the top four overall export destinations for these products because of the need from their robust commercial sectors.

business_locations.location_description: The West is home to many downstream markets and controls international trade with Pacific countries, as well as the United States' neighbors Mexico and Canada. California's sheer size, population, and control of the Pacific coast make it a popular location for manufacturers. Its shared border with Mexico also contributes to its presence in the manufacturing sector.

The Great Lakes region is the historic manufacturing backbone of the United States. Key up- and downstream markets are located in the region, namely the automotive industry. Illinois and Ohio are the largest states in the region for the manufacturing sector. This is because they are home to several downstream industries that

The Southeast region is popular among manufacturers because of its proximity to major markets and well-developed transportation infrastructure. This includes highways, airports and ports, making it easy for manufacturers to reach markets. Florida is a major trade hub. Its access to both the Atlantic Ocean and the Gulf of Mexico makes it a strategic location for international trade.

regulations_points.regulation_description: Copier and optical machinery manufacturers are subject to various federal, state and local laws and regulations relating to the protection of the environment. These laws and regulations impose limitations on the discharge of materials into the environment and require manufacturers to obtain licenses and operate in compliance with government regulations.

Internal data protection has been under the spotlight as major US companies have experienced breaches in data systems. Manufacturers transmit and store identifiable information of customers and employees as systems providers and employers. Consequently, manufacturers are subject to domestic and foreign regulations designed to protect this data.

Complying with production standards is also a significant priority for manufacturers in this industry. The American National Standards Institute (ANSI) oversees the introduction of norms and guidelines, regarding consumer safety and environmental protection that affect a wide range of industries.

barriers_points.barrier_description: The industry is mature, indicating high barriers to entry.
The level of industry assistance is low and steady, contributing to high barriers.
The high and steady level of globalization increases barriers to entry.

basis_points.basis_description: Import penetration is the main source of external competition, satisfying nearly half of domestic demand.
Some manufacturers manage to dominate their product segments and obtain significant market share, e.g. Xerox in photographic and photocopying equipment.

concentration_points.concentration_description: The industry has low concentration due to inclusion of many diverse product segments.
Some manufacturers dominate their niche product segments and obtain significant shares, e.g. Welbilt in commercial cooking equipment, Xerox in photocopying.

cost_factors.cost_factor_description: From optical lenses to commercial stoves, purchases form the highest individual cost across all product segments. Major drivers of purchase costs include the price and availability of metals like copper tubing, aluminum and nonferrous castings.

Wages are a key expense for manufacturers. Skilled workers are needed to operate the production line and manage day-to-day office activity. Still, manufacturers have been able to limit wage costs through automation.

capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_description: Advertising and branding also pose a problem for entrants. The higher costs and risks associated with overcoming existing brand loyalties dramatically boost advertising expenditure for new entrants.
Burgeoning manufacturers contend with volatile input prices for raw materials like plastics, metals and semiconductors. Also, they may have difficulty penetrating existing distribution networks.

volatility_points.volatility_description: Although revenue volatility varies by company size and product segment, revenue is determined by factors such as corporate profit, aggregate private investment on capital equipment, demand from downstream wholesalers and retailers and the volume of international trade.

Spending on materials for products consumes the largest share of industry revenue. Plastics, metals and semiconductors regularly fluctuate in price, making it difficult for manufacturers to pass costs down to consumers.

technological_change_points.technological_change_description: Product innovation is largely geared toward competing with digital products that have replaced industry goods.

FAQs.question: What is NAFEM?
FAQs.answer: The North American Association of Food Equipment Manufacturers (NAFEM) is an industry association that services the food equipment and supplies manufacturing industry. It has over 550 member companies that produce products such as food preparation, cooking, storage and table service equipment.

FAQs.question: What is I3A?
FAQs.answer: The International Imaging Industry Association (I3A) is an industry group that services the imaging, digital imaging and photographic industries. It acts as a spokesperson for manufacturers engaged in manufacturing imaging optical and imaging equipment and focuses on developing industry standards and dealing with environmental issues.

FAQs.question: What is NAMA?
FAQs.answer: The National Automatic Merchandising Association (NAMA) is a US trade association that services the vending, coffee service and food service industries, including on-site, commissary, catering and mobile services. Its members include service companies and equipment manufacturers, along with products and services suppliers.

FAQs.question: How do rising imports affect companies in this industry?
FAQs.answer: Rising imports weigh heavily on industry operators, which creates price-based competition for domestic manufacturers.

FAQs.question: Do exports offer opportunities for companies in this industry?
FAQs.answer: When the value of the dollar depreciates, there is a window of opportunity for domestic manufacturers to increase their revenue through exports.

FAQs.question: Do companies explore acquisition opportunities in areas with established infrastructure?
FAQs.answer: Consolidation in this industry is prevalent, with the industry's largest players acquiring smaller companies to boost the efficiency of their processes. Additionally, offshoring operations to developing nations is also a popular strategy.

FAQs.question: Do companies set up manufacturing facilities in lower-wage regions?
FAQs.answer: Industry operators have looked to set up manufacturing facilities in lower-wage regions of the country to boost profit and efficiency.

FAQs.question: Are companies investing in technology for a competitive edge?
FAQs.answer: Industry operators are investing in new technologies to provide high-value added products for consumers. Additionally, research and development is imperative in further developing product offerings.

FAQs.question: Have companies reduced wage costs through automation?
FAQs.answer: Industry operators have tried to reduce wage costs through more efficient processes, including automation of manual labor tasks.

FAQs.question: Have regulatory expenses impacted profitability?
FAQs.answer: Regulations have led industry companies to replace lower-cost inputs with more expensive, energy-efficient ones.

FAQs.question: How do companies stay ahead of regulations like energy-efficiency standards?
FAQs.answer: Industry operators are challenged by appliance-efficiency regulations. Operators stay ahead of the curve by following the regulations set forth, principally by the US Environmental Protection Agency.

FAQs.question: How do profit margins compare among competitors?
FAQs.answer: The industry's largest players have the highest profit as a result of increased efficiency. Additionally, profits vary depending on the major product lines that operators produce.

FAQs.question: How has input price volatility affected profit margins?
FAQs.answer: Despite increasing input prices, profit margin remains steady due to consistent commercial demand.

FAQs.question: What resources do companies dedicate to R&D and attracting qualified staff?
FAQs.answer: Many operators devote significant resources to research and development. These efforts are directed at the improvement of existing products and the timely development of new products.

FAQs.question: How do companies differentiate their products and access latest technology?
FAQs.answer: In addition to price, competition in this industry is based on quality, particularly concerning technological advancement. To continually advance, operators need access to the latest available and most efficient technology.

FAQs.question: How often are new products developed and how is success gauged?
FAQs.answer: Economies of scope are developed from a broad product range that enables the use of the same or similar skills or cost infrastructures.

FAQs.question: How can companies adapt to decelerating corporate profit growth?
FAQs.answer: This industry manufactures equipment primarily used for commercial purposes. Therefore, corporate profit for downstream businesses affects industry demand, as companies with higher profits can purchase more new office-related equipment.
